reviews.review:
Elden Ring felt like it’s the culmination of all FromSoftware games that came before it. It’s everything they learned from them and more. If you’ve played other FromSoftware games, you’ll stumble upon a lot of familiar things, scenarios, locations, enemies, bullshit, and they took all that and put it in a huge open world map.

The map itself is vague. If you like the “zero hands holding” approach, this is your game. Not only do you not know what to do next, but things are hard as they are in your average souls experience, you wander into the wrong neighborhood, and there goes all your runes.

This is the most polished experience from the series. It’s visually beautiful and beautifully crafted, the world has much variety, some copy pasted landmarks but also lots of unique places with good interiors and architecture. I know some people complain that some enemies repeat, but even with that, there are tons of variety in this aspect as well.

Unlocked new fear of insects, centipedes, ants, fingers? They replaced spiders with fingers, and I don't know which is worse now... 

I have mixed feelings about the gameplay. For most people, they nailed the combat in this one, and it's true, but there are some annoying things. 

Unlike DS2, you can attack and dodge quite a lot before running out of stamina, which promotes faster gameplay, and that's usually what people seek and enjoy. To balance that, bosses also unleash a fury of successive fast attacks, and sometimes the window during which you can attack without being punished is really small, so the fight ends up with more downtime (defense time) than attacking, and that can be boring. 

I'm not talking about op builds and cheeses, those exist, but I'm speaking of a normal first playthrough experience. 

It feels like mobs don't have a stamina bar as u do. That was a nice feature from Nioh, being able to see the enemy's stamina bar. 

Another issue is how huge bosses are, now it's not new, but man, it's becoming ridiculous. I know people loove to fight big bosses, but I use M&K because I like complete camera control, and even then, I don't even see all the boss. Some fights I don't see the hit because it's impossible to have all the boss within the camera frame, neither by locking the view nor by unlocking it. 

Other than that, I absolutely love the animations, the weapon variety, the spell effects, the class variety, and mix and matching, all the new features are fun to play with. 

On a more personal note, even though this game has everything, even things from previous souls games, more features, more work into it, I still think that experiencing similar features was more iconic in previous titles. If you're new to the genre, this game is a fantastic place to start. It has everything, and it's modern, but for me, I still find DS1 to be the most iconic and the most beautiful journey, but maybe cause I played it first, we will never know.

Disclaimer: For most people, I actually would recommend the game. But, for me personally, the more time passes the more flaws I see in the game, and my ultimate opinion on it is that it contains an all-time great game, but also a lot of junk that was never a problem in FromSoft's older titles.

Obviously the visual art is masterful. Obviously the music is some of the best ever to grace a video game. Obviously getting a big stick to beat your enemies' asses with while you roll around like a madman is awesome. Obviously the spectacle and beauty of the environments and bosses are breathtaking. All of these things can also be said about every previous soulsborne game.

Unfortunately, this game also contains a humongous map that is honestly exhausting to explore, and frequently that exploration rewards you with discovering a copy-pasted mine/cave that probably has some loot at the end that you will never use. The huge map also spreads its scant cast of NPCs further out than ever before, taking an obtuse and mysterious NPC quest system present in Dark Souls and stretching it to the point of being literally impossible for me to keep track of. You will run into NPCs that you haven't seen in 10 or 20 hours, and without a guide, how am I possibly supposed to remember what they said to me last time and know how to progress their storylines? It's just, "Huh, there is that weird guy I met like 2 IRL weeks ago. He looks cool, but what is he even doing again?" Simply put, the game is too big and too long for me, it just gets tiring and cumbersome, I seriously just wanted it to be over by the time I was 75% of the way through.

I'm also not a fan of a lot of the boss fights. It takes a problem that started in Dark Souls 3 and cranks it up even further, which is the design idea of, "If we just put a bonfire right outside the boss arena, we can make it a 3-phase clusterjam with movement cancelling and 69 different attacks for the player to memorize, and it won't matter if the player dies 20+ times because they can immediately retry!" Too me, this is so much less fun than the classic Dark Souls 1/2 challenge of battling your way through a gauntlet of enemies and traps and then fighting a challenging, but not overloaded boss as the cherry on top. It used to feel like a boss fight was your opportunity to prove that you have mastered an area and are ready to move on. In Elden Ring, a lot of boss fights feel like a tacked-on reflex and memorization challenge that is separate from the challenge of the area itself.

While I can appreciate that FromSoft tried going bigger and grander, I ultimately feel like they lost some of the old magic along the way, and Elden Ring ended up being annoying and fatiguing in a way that their previous titles never were for me. What a shame, as this is clearly their biggest hit, so I guess I'm in the minority. I can squint and see a 10/10 life-changing game in it, but ultimately the size and length of the game, some of the ridiculously complex bosses, and the copy-pasted open world elements distract from the solid core and drag the experience down. I can confidently say I won't be replaying this game, unlike Dark Souls 1 and 2, Bloodborne, and Armored Core 6, which all sound very enticing to return to.

I don't need to tell you that Elden Ring is a marvel of game design. There will, for better or worse, probably never be another game like it. I have never inhabited a world so deeply considered and detailed than the Lands Between, each step you take carries with it the footsteps of generations past. It's beautiful! If you care for a world with layers upon layers of history and civilization, Elden Ring is a tasty fuckin meal. Of course, as always, From's combat is top-notch. 
It is not a perfect game, but it is truly, truly magical for your first playthrough. My gripes are common refrains too - too many repeated enemies and bosses, the world is a little too big for its own good. Comes together to deserve every last bit of praise it gets, though.

Maidenless? Not Anymore. I came to the Lands Between with zero expectations and left with emotional damage, a broken controller, and 200+ hours played. Elden Ring is not just a game — it’s an obsession.

“What’s that in the distance?” (worst mistake of my life) Elden Ring’s open world is basically a trap. You see something cool far away, ride Torrent towards it, and suddenly you’re fighting a boss you were definitely not supposed to meet yet. And somehow… that’s the fun. No markers screaming at you, no hand-holding — just curiosity, punishment, and eventually triumph.

Git Gud, But Fair. Yes, it’s hard. Yes, you will die. A lot.
But every death feels like your fault. Every boss — from Margit teaching you humility, to Malenia reminding you that she has never known defeat — exists to test your patience, not waste your time. When you finally win, the dopamine hit is unreal.

Elden Ring doesn’t tell you its story. It dares you to discover it.
Godfrey’s exile, Marika’s defiance, Radahn holding back the stars while rotting, Ranni’s long game… the lore is deep, tragic, and beautifully fragmented. If you enjoy piecing together stories from item descriptions at 3 AM, this game will ruin you (in the best way).

Art Direction That Carries the Game The moment the soundtrack swells during a boss fight, you feel it. From Limgrave’s calm despair to Leyndell’s golden decay, the world tells its own story without saying a word.

“I started Elden Ring as a newcomer, and finished it having played every FromSoftware game — that alone should tell you what kind of masterpiece this is.”
Amazing game. I had a few crashes (had to play in windowed to stop that). But apart from that in my 139 hours on the game I had nothing but fun!

I like this game a lot. 

There's a lot of content and it can be a little overwhelming at first, but it's incredible that Fromsoft managed to make an open world souls game that gives you enough cool shit to find in areas that are distinct enough that you never really get bored of wanting to see what's behind the next door. 

If you're going to play with friends I'd recommend the Seamless Co-Op mod because it just allows for a more consistent playthrough, though a bit buggy at times.

My comment is mainly aimed at people who... like me are not huge JRPG or die & retry players and are thinking of trying Elden Ring as they first FromSoftware game. Because I think everyone else reading this, will most likely love this game. You still might be like me and hate it despite your best efforts. I actually wish I hadn't bought it or put so much time into it.

I've logged 60h+ because of a friend of mine who is a huge fan, convinced me to play co-op. So he held my hand and helped me (basically carried me) for the whole adventure.

- While the game is overall showcasing beautiful landscapes and epic scale, I can't get past the "dated" look it has in terms of noisiness in detail, the dirty textures, the illogical structures  and somewhat empty flat barren lands of nothing. I can't really get behind the generic look of some of the maidens or some of the un-describable monsters. That isn't to say there aren't pretty areas or characters, but it felt hugely inconsistent to me.
- I didn't feel like I experienced much of a story, or narrative elements beyond a few cutscenes, and obscure dialogues sprinkled across hours of gameplay. I am also the kind of player who needs a journal/quest log of some kind, to understand or remember what I've found, what I'm doing... and how any of that matters.
- The inventory, dialogue prompts, consumable/equipment switching all felt really clunky and badly designed to me. Like why do you'd have to make sure to talk to an NPC 6-8 times in a row to make sure you exhausted all topics with them to receive a reward... the only way to know ?? Another player who did it before...
- I kind of got the idea of the combat where you want to be meticulous and not button spammy... but I swear my weapon went through the enemies more than half of the time, and yet I'd go flying if they so much as looked at me funny.
- Quests and object unlocks and secrets and ridiculous platforming that all seem to be tied to "you just had to know, be incredibly stubborn/curious or did it by accident by playing this as if you were a game tester" Spending literally 20 minutes scaling a wall that doesn't look climbable, all to drop down somewhere to pick up one rare item that you wouldn't even know was there....

So....... even after 60h... I didn't like the game. I was not having fun and as much as I wanted to join my friend in his enthusiasm for FromSoftware games... I kept finding more things against it...

Another thing is that they don't care about people who do not live in English speaking countries because if you buy this game on Playstation outside of non-English countries, you might not even get to play the game in English version which makes it a big struggle for me to play with the weird ass translations in my Native language which is Thai. So I feel like the dev of this game doesn't really care much about feedbacks and are just lucky to have the fans protecting them all the time even on reddit (about the playstation controller mapping etc.) I see a lot of complaints on the languages too and still haven't received any changes since the release also.

They weren't kidding when they said this game was hard. 40 hours of pure agony. 40 hours of constant death. 40 hours of regret, sweat, and self-loathing... But I finally did it. I finally beat Soldier of Godrick.

Elden Ring is one of the most impressive games I have ever experienced. The open world feels huge, alive, and full of mysteries. Every location is unique, beautifully designed, and invites you to explore. The atmosphere ranges from mystical and calm to dark and overwhelming and that’s exactly what makes the game so captivating.

The soundtrack is absolutely masterful. The music fits perfectly in every situation, whether during exploration, intense boss fights, or quiet moments. It enhances the mood, builds tension, and often creates pure goosebumps.

The bosses are another major highlight. They are creatively designed, challenging, and incredibly epic in their presentation. Every fight feels like a special event. The lore and story, which gradually unfold, add a lot of depth and make the world even more fascinating.

For me, Elden Ring comes incredibly close to being a perfect game. It’s very near to what I would call a truly flawless and outstanding experience.

Elden Ring is an absolute masterpiece full of atmosphere, excitement, and unforgettable moments. A clear recommendation.

Ah.. Elden Ring. Seni incelemek, İstanbul’a benziyor. Biraz tatlı, biraz acı. Biraz emin, biraz değil. Üzümlü kekim mi diyeyim, kabusum mu? Karar vermem güç.

Evet, üstte belirttiğim gibi. Zor, bir o kadar da güzel bir oyun. Yoran, bir o kadar da haz veren bir oyun. İstanbul misali. 

Elden ring her şeyden önce muazzam dövüş mekanikleri olan, mükemmel atmosferi bulunan, zorlayıcı, etkileyici bir oyun diyerek başlamak isterim. Gaming dünyasının olmazsa olmazı gibi bir oyun bu. Soulslike’ı sevdirecek boyutlarda başarılı. Fakat öyle bir sıkıntısı var ki, siz sormayın ben söylemeyeyim. 

Oyunda bir mod kurulumu yardımıyla duo oynayabiliyorsunuz. Fakat bunun bir dezavantajı olacak. Eğer duo’ysanız, sürekli oyun dünyanızın raid yemesine hazır olun. Bu raidler o kadar saçma, o kadar aptalca ki, tüm oyunun güzelliğini gölgeliyor adeta. 

Anlamlandıramadığım bir şekilde pvpsi her daim laglı. 10000 megabit internete de sahip olsan, vuruşlar hep laglı bir şekilde rakibe gidiyor. Vurduğun halde canını azaltamıyorsun. İşin PvP kısmında dodge sisteminde sıkıntı var. 

Daha da garibi, bu raid esnasında gerçekleşen PvP düellosunun, hiçbir şekilde adil olmayışı. Gelen kişi itemsel ve level olarak sizden çok da güçlü oluyor. Bundan da saçması, siz bir boss fight’ının ortasında raid yiyorsunuz ve eksik pot’la oynamanız gerekiyor. Sırf bu sebeple oyuna dislike atasım var, ama bunu yapmadım. Çünkü bu, haksızlık ve duygularımla hareket ederek yaptığım bir puanlama olurdu.

Alınız efendim. İndirimde kaçırmayınız bu oyunu. Alıp da bir gün oynarım bea diyerek de almayınız. Hemen indirip başlayınız. Pişman olacağınızı sanmıyorum.

Keyifli oyular.

I am obviously not the typical Souls player. I liked Sekiro and Bloodborne and to a lesser extent DS1, 2 and 3, but I just found this to be dragged out way too much, be way to focused on making specific builds and so much essential stuff being hid around the massive world. It was just too much and not explained in any way. 

Often losing track of what you were supposed to do when sidetracked by some dungeon, and often you find yourself in areas that you are way underleveled for. Last part was especially aggregios to me, because the game felt more like a mmorpg grind rather than a souls-experience. Also, a ton of essential stuff is hidden in dungeons or other maps that are theoretically "optional".

At the end, I just wanted the game to be over so I could call it a day and not feel like I wasted my money, but that is more on me and my stubbornness I guess. Felt relief to be done with the bosses more so than accomplishment like I did with other entries. Especially because some had cutscenes you had to skip every time, some had annoying walk-backs, and others had annoying, tedious first phases. 

I understand why people like it. But I personally found it way too much, given the typical amount of repetition you need to do in order to progress a boss. A lot ended up feeling more like a chore than something I really wanted to progress because I couldn't wait to experience what was next.
